question: Define colour depth and explain its effect on image file size.
oldAnswer:
Colour depth is the number of bits used to represent each pixel
Greater colour depth allows more colours to be represented
... which increases the file size
... as more bits are needed for each pixel
suggestedAnswer: Bits used to represent the colour of a pixel.

question: Define embedded system and give an example.
oldAnswer: An embedded system is dedicated to a specific function within a larger system, e.g., a washing machine controller.
suggestedAnswer: Computer dedicated to a specific function within a larger system.

question: Explain why overflow occurs in 8-bit unsigned binary addition. Give an example.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
In 8-bit unsigned binary, the largest value is 255
The result of the addition exceeds 255
The most significant bit (carry bit) is discarded
... causing wrap-around
Example: 11111111₂ (255) + 00000001₂ (1) → 00000000₂
suggestedAnswer: Smallest unit of data; represents 0 or 1.

question: Calculate the file size of a 400×300 image with 16-bit colour depth, uncompressed.
suggestedAnswer: Smallest unit of data; represents 0 or 1.

question: Calculate the file size of a 30-second mono audio clip, 44.1 kHz sample rate, 16-bit resolution, uncompressed.
suggestedAnswer: Smallest unit of data; represents 0 or 1.

question: Explain why overflow occurs in 8-bit unsigned binary addition. Give an example.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
In 8-bit unsigned binary, the largest value is 255
The result of the addition exceeds 255
The most significant bit (carry bit) is discarded
... causing wrap-around
Example: 11111111₂ (255) + 00000001₂ (1) → 00000000₂
suggestedAnswer: Base-2 number system using digits 0 and 1.

question: Perform logical left shift of 3 places on binary number 10100011.
suggestedAnswer: Base-2 number system using digits 0 and 1.

question: Convert 11010110₂ to denary and hexadecimal.
oldAnswer: Denary: 214\nHexadecimal: D6
suggestedAnswer: Base-10 number system using digits 0–9.

question: Convert denary numbers 20, 32, and 165 to hexadecimal.
suggestedAnswer: Base-10 number system using digits 0–9.

question: Convert two's complement 10100011 to denary.
suggestedAnswer: Base-10 number system using digits 0–9.

question: Convert 11010110₂ to denary and hexadecimal.
oldAnswer: Denary: 214\nHexadecimal: D6
suggestedAnswer: Base-16 number system using 0–9 and A–F.

question: Give two reasons why ticket numbers are displayed as hexadecimal.
oldAnswer: 1. Shorter representation than binary\n2. Easier for humans to read
suggestedAnswer: Base-16 number system using 0–9 and A–F.

oldAnswer: It is a base 10 system

question: Explain why overflow occurs in 8-bit unsigned binary addition. Give an example.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
In 8-bit unsigned binary, the largest value is 255
The result of the addition exceeds 255
The most significant bit (carry bit) is discarded
... causing wrap-around
Example: 11111111₂ (255) + 00000001₂ (1) → 00000000₂
suggestedAnswer: Condition when a value exceeds the representable range.

question: Describe a difference between ASCII and Unicode and why Unicode is needed.
oldAnswer:
Difference:
ASCII uses 7 or 8 bits (per character)
Unicode uses 16 or 32 bits (per character)

Reason:
ASCII has a limited character set (Latin only)
Unicode covers all major languages/symbols (internationalization)
suggestedAnswer: 7/8-bit character encoding for Latin characters.

question: Explain why extended ASCII is insufficient for representing some languages.
oldAnswer: Extended ASCII provides 256 codes\n... which is insufficient for languages with many characters (e.g., Chinese/Japanese)\nUnicode supports thousands of code points
suggestedAnswer: 7/8-bit character encoding for Latin characters.

question: Describe a difference between ASCII and Unicode and why Unicode is needed.
oldAnswer:
Difference:
ASCII uses 7 or 8 bits (per character)
Unicode uses 16 or 32 bits (per character)

Reason:
ASCII has a limited character set (Latin only)
Unicode covers all major languages/symbols (internationalization)
suggestedAnswer: Universal character encoding standard with code points.

question: State how sample rate and resolution affect sound quality and file size.
oldAnswer:
Sample rate: Number of samples taken per second
Higher sample rate improves sound accuracy/quality
... but increases file size

Resolution: Number of bits per sample
Higher resolution improves dynamic range/quality
... but increases file size
suggestedAnswer: Number of pixels in each dimension of an image.

question: Calculate the file size of a 30-second mono audio clip, 44.1 kHz sample rate, 16-bit resolution, uncompressed.
suggestedAnswer: Number of pixels in each dimension of an image.

question: Calculate the file size of a 400×300 image with 16-bit colour depth, uncompressed.
suggestedAnswer: Bits used to represent the colour of a pixel.

question: State how sample rate and resolution affect sound quality and file size.
oldAnswer:
Sample rate: Number of samples taken per second
Higher sample rate improves sound accuracy/quality
... but increases file size

Resolution: Number of bits per sample
Higher resolution improves dynamic range/quality
... but increases file size
suggestedAnswer: Samples per second measured in Hz.

question: Calculate the file size of a 30-second mono audio clip, 44.1 kHz sample rate, 16-bit resolution, uncompressed.
suggestedAnswer: Samples per second measured in Hz.

question: Compare lossless and lossy compression with a suitable use case for each.
oldAnswer:
Lossless:
No data is lost/original file can be recreated perfectly
Use: Text files/Source code/Spreadsheets

Lossy:
Some data is permanently removed/discarded (to reduce size)
Use: Images (JPEG)/Audio (MP3)/Video
suggestedAnswer: Reducing file size while preserving information.

question: Describe what a dictionary-based compression method does in general terms.
oldAnswer: Builds a dictionary/index of frequent patterns/words\nReplaces instances of patterns with short references/tokens to the dictionary
suggestedAnswer: Reducing file size while preserving information.

question: Compare lossless and lossy compression with a suitable use case for each.
oldAnswer:
Lossless:
No data is lost/original file can be recreated perfectly
Use: Text files/Source code/Spreadsheets

Lossy:
Some data is permanently removed/discarded (to reduce size)
Use: Images (JPEG)/Audio (MP3)/Video
suggestedAnswer: Compression that removes some information.

question:
Tick (✓) one box to show which of the terms is not a method for transmitting data.
A serial
B simplex
C parallel
D parity
oldAnswer: D parity
suggestedAnswer: Communication in one direction only.

question: Explain the difference between simplex, half-duplex and full-duplex data transmission.
oldAnswer:
Simplex:
Data flows in one direction only
Example: Keyboard to CPU

Half-duplex:
Data flows in both directions but not at the same time
Example: Walkie-talkie

Full-duplex:
Data flows in both directions simultaneously
Example: Telephone call
suggestedAnswer: Communication in one direction only.

question: Explain the difference between simplex, half-duplex and full-duplex data transmission.
oldAnswer:
Simplex:
Data flows in one direction only
Example: Keyboard to CPU

Half-duplex:
Data flows in both directions but not at the same time
Example: Walkie-talkie

Full-duplex:
Data flows in both directions simultaneously
Example: Telephone call
suggestedAnswer: Communication both ways but not at the same time.

question: Explain the difference between simplex, half-duplex and full-duplex data transmission.
oldAnswer:
Simplex:
Data flows in one direction only
Example: Keyboard to CPU

Half-duplex:
Data flows in both directions but not at the same time
Example: Walkie-talkie

Full-duplex:
Data flows in both directions simultaneously
Example: Telephone call
suggestedAnswer: Communication both ways simultaneously.

question: Describe the structure of a data packet.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
A packet is split into three different sections
... the header
... the payload
... the trailer
suggestedAnswer: Unit of data sent across a network with header and payload.

question: Packet switching is used to transmit the data packets across the network.\nIdentify the device that controls which path is taken by each data packet.
oldAnswer: Router
suggestedAnswer: Unit of data sent across a network with header and payload.

question: Explain what a checksum is and how it is used.
oldAnswer:
A checksum is a value computed from the data
The sender transmits it with the packet
The receiver recomputes the checksum
... and compares it to the received checksum to detect errors
suggestedAnswer: Calculated value used to detect errors in data.

question: Describe how an Automatic Repeat Request (ARQ) system is used to check for errors.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The sender transmits a data packet
... and waits for an acknowledgement (ACK)
If no ACK is received within a timeout period
... or if a negative acknowledgement (NACK) is received
The sender retransmits the packet
This process repeats until an ACK is received or a limit is reached
suggestedAnswer: Automatic repeat request protocol for retransmission.

question: Packet switching is used to transmit the data packets across the network.\nIdentify the device that controls which path is taken by each data packet.
oldAnswer: Router
suggestedAnswer: Data split into packets routed independently.

question: Explain the function of the ALU and Control Unit in a CPU.
oldAnswer: The ALU performs arithmetic and logic operations; the Control Unit fetches, decodes and coordinates execution of instructions.
suggestedAnswer: Central processing unit executing instructions.

question: Explain how clock speed and cache size affect CPU performance.
oldAnswer: Clock speed: Higher speed means more cycles per second, so more instructions can be processed.\nCache size: Larger cache stores more frequently used instructions/data closer to the CPU, reducing access time compared to RAM.
suggestedAnswer: Central processing unit executing instructions.

question: Explain the function of the ALU and Control Unit in a CPU.
oldAnswer: The ALU performs arithmetic and logic operations; the Control Unit fetches, decodes and coordinates execution of instructions.
suggestedAnswer: Arithmetic logic unit performing operations.

question: Explain the function of the ALU and Control Unit in a CPU.
oldAnswer: The ALU performs arithmetic and logic operations; the Control Unit fetches, decodes and coordinates execution of instructions.
suggestedAnswer: Directs operations of the processor.

question: Explain how clock speed and cache size affect CPU performance.
oldAnswer: Clock speed: Higher speed means more cycles per second, so more instructions can be processed.\nCache size: Larger cache stores more frequently used instructions/data closer to the CPU, reducing access time compared to RAM.
suggestedAnswer: Generates timing signals controlling the processor.

question: Compare RAM and ROM with one use case for each.
oldAnswer: RAM is volatile working memory used during program execution. ROM is non-volatile and stores firmware that runs at start-up.
suggestedAnswer: Volatile main memory for programs and data in use.

question: Compare RAM and ROM with one use case for each.
oldAnswer: RAM is volatile working memory used during program execution. ROM is non-volatile and stores firmware that runs at start-up.
suggestedAnswer:
Any one from:
• Permanently store instructions (in ROM)
• Stores instructions to boot up/start up the computer
• Provides the operating system with a platform to run on
• Controls/manages/allows communication with hardware
• Store instructions securely (to stop them being easily corrupted)

question: Name the three buses in Von Neumann architecture and state their roles.
oldAnswer: Data bus carries data; Address bus carries memory addresses; Control bus carries control signals.
suggestedAnswer: Shared memory for instructions and data.

question: Give one example each of an input device, output device and sensor.
oldAnswer: Input: keyboard; Output: monitor; Sensor: temperature sensor.
suggestedAnswer: Hardware used to enter data into a system.

question: Give one example each of an input device, output device and sensor.

question: Give one example each of an input device, output device and sensor.
oldAnswer: Input: keyboard; Output: monitor; Sensor: temperature sensor.

question: State one advantage and one disadvantage of SSD compared to HDD.
oldAnswer: Advantage: faster access and no moving parts. Disadvantage: typically higher cost per GB.
suggestedAnswer: Magnetic storage using spinning disks.

question: State one advantage and one disadvantage of SSD compared to HDD.
oldAnswer: Advantage: faster access and no moving parts. Disadvantage: typically higher cost per GB.
suggestedAnswer: Solid-state storage using flash memory.

question: Describe how data is written to and read from optical storage.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
A laser beam is used to read/write data
Data is stored as pits and lands
... on a spiral track
When reading, the laser is reflected differently by pits and lands
... which is interpreted as binary 1s and 0s
suggestedAnswer: Storage using lasers to read/write data.

question: Explain the difference between system software and application software.
oldAnswer: System software manages and supports computer operations; application software performs user-facing tasks.
suggestedAnswer: Any two from:\n• System software manages/maintains the hardware/software\n• Applications software allows the user to perform tasks

question: Explain the difference between system software and application software.
oldAnswer: System software manages and supports computer operations; application software performs user-facing tasks.
suggestedAnswer: Any two from:\n• System software manages/maintains the hardware/software\n• Applications software allows the user to perform tasks

question: State two functions of an operating system.
oldAnswer: Examples: memory management, file management, process scheduling, device control, security.
suggestedAnswer:
Any three from:
• It performs the basic functions of a computer
• It manages the hardware
• It provides a platform to run software

question: Compare CLI and GUI with one advantage of each.
oldAnswer:
CLI:
Allows precise control via commands
... uses fewer system resources

GUI:
More intuitive/easier for beginners
... allows WIMP interactions (windows, icons, menus, pointer)
suggestedAnswer: Command-line interface using typed commands.

question: Compare CLI and GUI with one advantage of each.
oldAnswer:
CLI:
Allows precise control via commands
... uses fewer system resources

GUI:
More intuitive/easier for beginners
... allows WIMP interactions (windows, icons, menus, pointer)
suggestedAnswer: Graphical user interface using windows, icons and menus.

question: Compare compiler and interpreter.
oldAnswer: A compiler translates the whole program into object code before execution; an interpreter translates and executes line by line at runtime.
suggestedAnswer:
Two from for each compiler and interpreter.
Compiler
• Checks all code before executing any code
• Produces error report with all errors found for the whole code (before translating/running any of the code)
• Produces executable file
Interpreter
• Checks/translates one line of code and then executes it before moving on to the next line
• Stops when an error is found
• … when corrected the program can be run from the same position // allows error correction in real time

question: Compare compiler and interpreter.
oldAnswer: A compiler translates the whole program into object code before execution; an interpreter translates and executes line by line at runtime.
suggestedAnswer:
Two from for each compiler and interpreter.
Compiler
• Checks all code before executing any code

• Produces executable file
Interpreter
• Checks/translates one line of code and then executes it before moving on to the next line
• Stops when an error is found
• … when corrected the program can be run from the same position // allows error correction in real time

question: State two advantages of using a High-Level Language (HLL) compared to a Low-Level Language (LLL).
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
Easier to understand/read/write (for humans)
... as it uses English-like statements
Easier to debug/find errors
Portable/machine independent
... code can run on different hardware without rewrite
suggestedAnswer: Language close to human readability and abstraction.

question: State two advantages of using a High-Level Language (HLL) compared to a Low-Level Language (LLL).
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
Easier to understand/read/write (for humans)
... as it uses English-like statements
Easier to debug/find errors
Portable/machine independent
... code can run on different hardware without rewrite
suggestedAnswer: Language close to machine operations and hardware.

question: State one advantage of open-source software and one advantage of proprietary software.
oldAnswer: Open-source: free to use/modify; community support; transparency.\nProprietary: dedicated vendor support; regular updates; polished features.
suggestedAnswer: Software licensed with restricted use and access.

question: Describe the role of DNS in accessing websites.
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
A user enters a URL/domain name in the browser
The DNS system is queried to resolve the name
DNS servers maintain a distributed database of domain names and IP addresses
If the local DNS does not have the record, it queries other DNS servers
The DNS returns the corresponding IP address to the client
The browser uses the IP address to connect to the web server
DNS may cache results to speed up future lookups
suggestedAnswer: Domain Name System translating names to IP addresses.

question: Explain the difference between HTTP and HTTPS.
oldAnswer:
HTTP:
Data is sent in plain text
... so it can be intercepted/read by a third party
Does not provide authentication of the server

HTTPS:
Uses TLS/SSL to encrypt communication
... so intercepted data cannot be understood
Verifies the identity of the web server (via digital certificates)
suggestedAnswer: HyperText Transfer Protocol for web communication.

question: Explain the difference between HTTP and HTTPS.
oldAnswer:
HTTP:
Data is sent in plain text
... so it can be intercepted/read by a third party
Does not provide authentication of the server

HTTPS:
Uses TLS/SSL to encrypt communication
... so intercepted data cannot be understood
Verifies the identity of the web server (via digital certificates)
suggestedAnswer: Secure version of HTTP using TLS encryption.

question: State two advantages of using HTTPS when shopping online.
oldAnswer: Encrypts data to prevent interception/read by third parties\nAuthenticates the web server via digital certificates
suggestedAnswer: Secure version of HTTP using TLS encryption.

question: Explain the purpose of a cookie.
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
To store user preferences/settings
... e.g., language choice, theme
To track user browsing habits/analytics
To implement shopping carts
... holding items while user browses
To keep a user logged in (session management)
suggestedAnswer: Small data stored by a browser for a website.

question: Explain how a firewall helps protect a network.
oldAnswer:
Monitors and filters incoming/outgoing traffic
Blocks unauthorised access based on rules
Can prevent certain types of attacks (e.g., port scans)
Allows permitted traffic while denying suspicious connections
suggestedAnswer: Network security system controlling traffic.

question: State two methods to protect users from phishing.
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
Educate users to check URLs/email addresses carefully
Use spam filters to block suspicious emails
Do not click links in unsolicited emails
Check for the padlock symbol/HTTPS
suggestedAnswer: Fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive information.

question: Explain the difference between phishing and pharming.
oldAnswer:
Phishing:
Involves sending fraudulent emails/messages
... to trick users into revealing personal data (by clicking links)

Pharming:
Involves malicious code installed on a user's hard drive or web server
... which redirects the user to a fake website (even if correct URL is typed)
... without the user's knowledge
suggestedAnswer: Fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive information.

question: Describe what a Trojan horse is and one way it can be spread.
oldAnswer: Trojan horse: Malware disguised as legitimate software that performs malicious actions when executed\nSpread: Via email attachments or through downloads from untrusted/malicious websites
suggestedAnswer: Malware disguised as legitimate software.

question: Explain how a digital signature is used to verify the authenticity of a document.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
A hash/digest of the document is created
... using a hashing algorithm
The hash is encrypted using the sender's private key
... to create the digital signature
The receiver decrypts the signature using the sender's public key
... to get the original hash
The receiver recalculates the hash of the received document
If the two hashes match, the document is authentic and unaltered
suggestedAnswer: Cryptographic proof of content integrity and origin.

question: Describe how a Bubble Sort algorithm sorts a list of numbers into ascending order.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The algorithm loops through the list
It compares each pair of adjacent elements
If they are in the wrong order, it swaps them
It records that a swap has occurred
It repeats the loop until a pass is made with no swaps
suggestedAnswer: Finite sequence of steps to solve a problem.

question: Trace this pseudocode and state the final value of total given input n=5.
oldAnswer: For i from 1 to 5, total accumulates 15. Final value: 15.
suggestedAnswer: Structured English describing algorithms independent of language.

question: Explain the difference between selection and iteration using pseudocode examples.
oldAnswer: Selection uses if/else to choose a path; iteration uses loops to repeat steps. Example: IF X>0 THEN...; FOR i=1 TO n ...
suggestedAnswer: Structured English describing algorithms independent of language.

question: Identify the standard flowchart symbol used for an assignment or process.
oldAnswer: Rectangle
suggestedAnswer: Diagram representing sequence and control flow.

question: Explain the purpose of a trace table.
oldAnswer: To manually track the values of variables as the code executes, allowing logic errors to be identified.
suggestedAnswer: Table tracking variable values step by step.

question: Compare Linear Search and Binary Search.
oldAnswer: Linear search checks every item in sequence; it works on any list but is slow for large lists. Binary search keeps dividing the list in half; it is much faster but requires the list to be sorted.
suggestedAnswer: Searching sequentially through a list.

question: Compare Linear Search and Binary Search.
oldAnswer: Linear search checks every item in sequence; it works on any list but is slow for large lists. Binary search keeps dividing the list in half; it is much faster but requires the list to be sorted.
suggestedAnswer: Searching a sorted list by halving the search space.

question: Describe how a Bubble Sort algorithm sorts a list of numbers into ascending order.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The algorithm loops through the list
It compares each pair of adjacent elements
If they are in the wrong order, it swaps them
It records that a swap has occurred
It repeats the loop until a pass is made with no swaps
suggestedAnswer: Repeatedly swapping adjacent out-of-order elements.

question: Give two reasons why ticket numbers are displayed as hexadecimal.
oldAnswer: 1. Shorter representation than binary\n2. Easier for humans to read
suggestedAnswer: Base-2 number system using digits 0 and 1.

question: Identify correct statement about logical left shift of 2 places.
oldAnswer: It would multiply the binary number by 4

question: Describe a difference between ASCII and Unicode and why Unicode is needed.
oldAnswer:
Difference:
ASCII uses 7 or 8 bits (per character)
Unicode uses 16 or 32 bits (per character)

Reason:
ASCII has a limited character set (Latin only)
Unicode covers all major languages/symbols (internationalization)

question: Define colour depth and explain its effect on image file size.
oldAnswer:
Colour depth is the number of bits used to represent each pixel
Greater colour depth allows more colours to be represented
... which increases the file size
... as more bits are needed for each pixel
suggestedAnswer: Smallest addressable element of a raster image.

question: Serial data transmission is used to transmit the data packets across the network.\nExplain why serial data transmission is used to transmit the data packets.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
The network may be spread over a long distance ...
... so it is more reliable
Bits will be sent/arrive in sequence
...so bits less likely to be skewed
Less crosstalk/interference
... so less likely to have errors
The data may not need to be transmitted at a fast speed // data transmission speed of serial is adequate
The cables in the network only use serial transmission
suggestedAnswer: Bits sent one after another over a single channel.

question: Data is broken down into smaller units to be transmitted from one device to another.\nGive the name of the unit that data is broken down into.
oldAnswer: Packet
suggestedAnswer: Unit of data sent across a network with header and payload.

question: Describe how an Automatic Repeat Request (ARQ) system is used to check for errors.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The sender transmits a data packet
... and waits for an acknowledgement (ACK)
If no ACK is received within a timeout period
... or if a negative acknowledgement (NACK) is received
The sender retransmits the packet
This process repeats until an ACK is received or a limit is reached
suggestedAnswer: Unit of data sent across a network with header and payload.

question: Explain what a checksum is and how it is used.
oldAnswer:
A checksum is a value computed from the data
The sender transmits it with the packet
The receiver recomputes the checksum
... and compares it to the received checksum to detect errors
suggestedAnswer: Unit of data sent across a network with header and payload.

question: Describe the structure of a data packet.

A packet is split into three different sections

... the header

Any three from:

... the header
... the payload
... the trailer

question: Explain how clock speed and cache size affect CPU performance.
oldAnswer: Clock speed: Higher speed means more cycles per second, so more instructions can be processed.\nCache size: Larger cache stores more frequently used instructions/data closer to the CPU, reducing access time compared to RAM.
suggestedAnswer: Volatile main memory for programs and data in use.

question: Explain the purpose of Virtual Memory.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
It is used when RAM is full
Data not currently in use is moved from RAM to secondary storage (HDD/SSD)
... creating 'pages'
It extends the available memory for running programs
Data is swapped back to RAM when needed
suggestedAnswer: Volatile main memory for programs and data in use.

question: Name the three buses in Von Neumann architecture and state their roles.
oldAnswer: Data bus carries data; Address bus carries memory addresses; Control bus carries control signals.
suggestedAnswer: Set of wires carrying data, addresses and control signals.

question: Describe the steps of the Fetch-Execute cycle.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The PC holds the address of the next instruction
The address is copied to the MAR
The address is sent along the address bus
The instruction is fetched from that address in memory
... and transferred to the MDR
The instruction is sent to the CIR
The PC is incremented
The instruction is decoded and executed
suggestedAnswer: Set of wires carrying data, addresses and control signals.

question: Name the three buses in Von Neumann architecture and state their roles.
oldAnswer: Data bus carries data; Address bus carries memory addresses; Control bus carries control signals.
suggestedAnswer: Transfers actual data between components.

question: Name the three buses in Von Neumann architecture and state their roles.
oldAnswer: Data bus carries data; Address bus carries memory addresses; Control bus carries control signals.
suggestedAnswer: Carries memory addresses for data access.

question: Describe the steps of the Fetch-Execute cycle.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The PC holds the address of the next instruction
The address is copied to the MAR
The address is sent along the address bus
The instruction is fetched from that address in memory
... and transferred to the MDR
The instruction is sent to the CIR
The PC is incremented
The instruction is decoded and executed
suggestedAnswer: Carries memory addresses for data access.

question: Name the three buses in Von Neumann architecture and state their roles.
oldAnswer: Data bus carries data; Address bus carries memory addresses; Control bus carries control signals.
suggestedAnswer: Carries control signals coordinating operations.

question: A greenhouse system controls temperature automatically. Describe how the system uses sensors and actuators to maintain temperature.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The temperature sensor constantly measures the temperature
It sends analogue data to the ADC
... which converts it to digital data for the microprocessor
The microprocessor compares the reading to a pre-set value
If temperature < pre-set value, it signals the actuator
... to turn on the heater
If temperature > pre-set value, it signals the actuator to turn off the heater/open windows
suggestedAnswer: Device detecting physical properties to produce data.

question: A greenhouse system controls temperature automatically. Describe how the system uses sensors and actuators to maintain temperature.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The temperature sensor constantly measures the temperature
It sends analogue data to the ADC
... which converts it to digital data for the microprocessor
The microprocessor compares the reading to a pre-set value
If temperature < pre-set value, it signals the actuator
... to turn on the heater
If temperature > pre-set value, it signals the actuator to turn off the heater/open windows
suggestedAnswer: Device converting data signals into physical action.

question: Explain the purpose of Virtual Memory.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
It is used when RAM is full
Data not currently in use is moved from RAM to secondary storage (HDD/SSD)
... creating 'pages'
It extends the available memory for running programs
Data is swapped back to RAM when needed
suggestedAnswer: Non-volatile storage for long-term data.

It is used when RAM is full

... creating 'pages'

question: Explain the purpose of Virtual Memory.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
It is used when RAM is full
Data not currently in use is moved from RAM to secondary storage (HDD/SSD)
... creating 'pages'
It extends the available memory for running programs
Data is swapped back to RAM when needed
suggestedAnswer: Solid-state storage using flash memory.

question: Identify one storage device built into a portable tablet computer.
oldAnswer: SSD // Solid-state drive // Solid-state (device)
suggestedAnswer: Solid-state storage using flash memory.

question: State two functions of an operating system.
oldAnswer: Examples: memory management, file management, process scheduling, device control, security.

question: State two functions of an operating system.
oldAnswer: Examples: memory management, file management, process scheduling, device control, security.

question: State two functions of an operating system.
oldAnswer: Examples: memory management, file management, process scheduling, device control, security.

question: State two functions of an operating system.
oldAnswer: Examples: memory management, file management, process scheduling, device control, security.

question: Explain why a programmer might choose to write code in Assembly Language.
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
To have direct control over the hardware
To write code that occupies less memory
To write code that executes faster/more efficiently
No need for a compiler/interpreter (only assembler needed)
Specific hardware drivers often require low-level access
suggestedAnswer:
Two from for each compiler and interpreter.
Compiler
• Checks all code before executing any code
• Produces error report with all errors found for the whole code (before translating/running any of the code)
• Produces executable file
Interpreter
• Checks/translates one line of code and then executes it before moving on to the next line
• Stops when an error is found
• … when corrected the program can be run from the same position // allows error correction in real time

question: Explain why a programmer might choose to write code in Assembly Language.

• Stops when an error is found
• … when corrected the program can be run from the same position // allows error correction in real time

To write code that occupies less memory

question: Compare compiler and interpreter.
oldAnswer: A compiler translates the whole program into object code before execution; an interpreter translates and executes line by line at runtime.
suggestedAnswer: Machine code produced by a translator.

question: Describe the role of DNS in accessing websites.
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
A user enters a URL/domain name in the browser
The DNS system is queried to resolve the name
DNS servers maintain a distributed database of domain names and IP addresses
If the local DNS does not have the record, it queries other DNS servers
The DNS returns the corresponding IP address to the client
The browser uses the IP address to connect to the web server
DNS may cache results to speed up future lookups
suggestedAnswer: Uniform Resource Locator identifying a resource.

question: Explain the difference between phishing and pharming.
oldAnswer:
Phishing:
Involves sending fraudulent emails/messages
... to trick users into revealing personal data (by clicking links)

Pharming:
Involves malicious code installed on a user's hard drive or web server
... which redirects the user to a fake website (even if correct URL is typed)
... without the user's knowledge
suggestedAnswer: Uniform Resource Locator identifying a resource.

question: Describe the role of DNS in accessing websites.

A user enters a URL/domain name in the browser
The DNS system is queried to resolve the name
DNS servers maintain a distributed database of domain names and IP addresses
If the local DNS does not have the record, it queries other DNS servers
The DNS returns the corresponding IP address to the client
The browser uses the IP address to connect to the web server
DNS may cache results to speed up future lookups
suggestedAnswer: Human-readable address of an internet resource.

question: State two methods to protect users from phishing.
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
Educate users to check URLs/email addresses carefully
Use spam filters to block suspicious emails
Do not click links in unsolicited emails
Check for the padlock symbol/HTTPS
suggestedAnswer: Secure version of HTTP using TLS encryption.

question: State two methods to protect users from phishing.

question: Describe what a Trojan horse is and one way it can be spread.
oldAnswer: Trojan horse: Malware disguised as legitimate software that performs malicious actions when executed\nSpread: Via email attachments or through downloads from untrusted/malicious websites
suggestedAnswer: Electronic mail system for messages.

question: Explain what a denial-of-service (DoS) attack is and state one method to prevent it.
oldAnswer: DoS attack: A malicious attempt to make a network or service unavailable by overwhelming it with traffic/requests\nPrevention: Use a firewall to filter incoming traffic or apply rate limiting to block excessive requests
suggestedAnswer: Network security system controlling traffic.

question: Describe what a Trojan horse is and one way it can be spread.
oldAnswer: Trojan horse: Malware disguised as legitimate software that performs malicious actions when executed\nSpread: Via email attachments or through downloads from untrusted/malicious websites
suggestedAnswer: Malicious software designed to cause harm.

question: Explain the difference between HTTP and HTTPS.
oldAnswer:
HTTP:
Data is sent in plain text
... so it can be intercepted/read by a third party
Does not provide authentication of the server

HTTPS:
Uses TLS/SSL to encrypt communication
... so intercepted data cannot be understood
Verifies the identity of the web server (via digital certificates)
suggestedAnswer: Protocols providing secure communication.

question: Describe the process of SSL/TLS handshaking.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The client sends a request to the server to establish a secure connection
The server sends its digital certificate to the client
... which includes the server's public key
The client verifies the digital certificate (authenticity and date)
The client generates a session key
... encrypts it with the server's public key
... and sends it to the server
The server decrypts the session key with its private key
Both parties now use the session key for encrypted communication
suggestedAnswer: Electronic document verifying identity and public key.

question: Explain the difference between HTTP and HTTPS.
oldAnswer:
HTTP:
Data is sent in plain text
... so it can be intercepted/read by a third party
Does not provide authentication of the server

HTTPS:
Uses TLS/SSL to encrypt communication
... so intercepted data cannot be understood
Verifies the identity of the web server (via digital certificates)
suggestedAnswer: Verifying user identity.

question: Identify three types of test data used to test a system.
oldAnswer: Normal data (valid/typical), Boundary data (extreme ends of valid range), Erroneous/Abnormal data (invalid).
suggestedAnswer: Typical valid inputs expected during regular use.

question: Identify three types of test data used to test a system.
oldAnswer: Normal data (valid/typical), Boundary data (extreme ends of valid range), Erroneous/Abnormal data (invalid).
suggestedAnswer: Inputs at the extremes of acceptable ranges.

question: Explain RLE and when it is effective.
oldAnswer:
Run-length encoding stores consecutive identical values as a count and the value
Example: AAAAA becomes 5A
Effective for data with long runs of repeated values (e.g., simple graphics)
Not effective for random data
suggestedAnswer: Images defined using geometric primitives.

question: Explain why overflow occurs in 8-bit unsigned binary addition. Give an example.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
In 8-bit unsigned binary, the largest value is 255
The result of the addition exceeds 255
The most significant bit (carry bit) is discarded
... causing wrap-around
Example: 11111111₂ (255) + 00000001₂ (1) → 00000000₂
suggestedAnswer: Bits transmitted/stored per second.

question: Calculate the file size of a 400×300 image with 16-bit colour depth, uncompressed.
suggestedAnswer: Bits transmitted/stored per second.

question: State how sample rate and resolution affect sound quality and file size.
oldAnswer:
Sample rate: Number of samples taken per second
Higher sample rate improves sound accuracy/quality
... but increases file size

Resolution: Number of bits per sample
Higher resolution improves dynamic range/quality
... but increases file size
suggestedAnswer: Bits transmitted/stored per second.

question: Calculate the file size of a 30-second mono audio clip, 44.1 kHz sample rate, 16-bit resolution, uncompressed.
suggestedAnswer: Bits transmitted/stored per second.

question: State how sample rate and resolution affect sound quality and file size.
oldAnswer:
Sample rate: Number of samples taken per second
Higher sample rate improves sound accuracy/quality
... but increases file size

Resolution: Number of bits per sample
Higher resolution improves dynamic range/quality
... but increases file size
suggestedAnswer: Bits used to store each sample’s amplitude.

question: Calculate the file size of a 30-second mono audio clip, 44.1 kHz sample rate, 16-bit resolution, uncompressed.
suggestedAnswer: Bits used to store each sample’s amplitude.

question: Compare lossless and lossy compression with a suitable use case for each.
oldAnswer:
Lossless:
No data is lost/original file can be recreated perfectly
Use: Text files/Source code/Spreadsheets

Lossy:
Some data is permanently removed/discarded (to reduce size)
Use: Images (JPEG)/Audio (MP3)/Video
suggestedAnswer: Compression without losing information.

question: Describe what a dictionary-based compression method does in general terms.
oldAnswer: Builds a dictionary/index of frequent patterns/words\nReplaces instances of patterns with short references/tokens to the dictionary
suggestedAnswer: Compression without losing information.

question: Describe what a dictionary-based compression method does in general terms.
oldAnswer: Builds a dictionary/index of frequent patterns/words\nReplaces instances of patterns with short references/tokens to the dictionary
suggestedAnswer: Compression that removes some information.

question: Explain RLE and when it is effective.
oldAnswer:
Run-length encoding stores consecutive identical values as a count and the value
Example: AAAAA becomes 5A
Effective for data with long runs of repeated values (e.g., simple graphics)
Not effective for random data
suggestedAnswer: Encoding consecutive repeated values as count-value pairs.

question:
Tick (✓) one box to show which of the terms is not a method for transmitting data.
A serial
B simplex
C parallel
D parity
oldAnswer: D parity
suggestedAnswer: Bits sent one after another over a single channel.

question: Explain the difference between simplex, half-duplex and full-duplex data transmission.
oldAnswer:
Simplex:
Data flows in one direction only
Example: Keyboard to CPU

Half-duplex:
Data flows in both directions but not at the same time
Example: Walkie-talkie

Full-duplex:
Data flows in both directions simultaneously
Example: Telephone call
suggestedAnswer: Bits sent one after another over a single channel.

question: Serial data transmission is used to transmit the data packets across the network.\nExplain why serial data transmission is used to transmit the data packets.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
The network may be spread over a long distance ...
... so it is more reliable
Bits will be sent/arrive in sequence
...so bits less likely to be skewed
Less crosstalk/interference
... so less likely to have errors
The data may not need to be transmitted at a fast speed // data transmission speed of serial is adequate
The cables in the network only use serial transmission
suggestedAnswer: Multiple bits sent simultaneously across several channels.

question:
Tick (✓) one box to show which of the terms is not a method for transmitting data.
A serial
B simplex
C parallel
D parity
oldAnswer: D parity
suggestedAnswer: Multiple bits sent simultaneously across several channels.

question: Explain the difference between simplex, half-duplex and full-duplex data transmission.
oldAnswer:
Simplex:
Data flows in one direction only
Example: Keyboard to CPU

Half-duplex:
Data flows in both directions but not at the same time
Example: Walkie-talkie

Full-duplex:
Data flows in both directions simultaneously
Example: Telephone call
suggestedAnswer: Multiple bits sent simultaneously across several channels.

question:

A serial
B simplex
C parallel
D parity
oldAnswer: D parity
suggestedAnswer: Bit added to make the total number of 1s even/odd.

question: Describe parity bits and a limitation of parity checking.
oldAnswer: Parity adds a bit to make the number of 1s even or odd\nLimitation: it detects single-bit errors\n... but not all multi-bit errors (e.g., two-bit flips retain parity)
suggestedAnswer: Bit added to make the total number of 1s even/odd.

question:
Tick (✓) one box to show which of the terms is not a method for transmitting data.
A serial
B simplex
C parallel
D parity
oldAnswer: D parity
suggestedAnswer: Parity method ensuring an even number of 1s.

question: Describe parity bits and a limitation of parity checking.
oldAnswer: Parity adds a bit to make the number of 1s even or odd\nLimitation: it detects single-bit errors\n... but not all multi-bit errors (e.g., two-bit flips retain parity)
suggestedAnswer: Parity method ensuring an even number of 1s.

A serial

D parity
oldAnswer: D parity

question: Describe parity bits and a limitation of parity checking.

suggestedAnswer: Parity method ensuring an odd number of 1s.

question: Describe the structure of a data packet.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
A packet is split into three different sections
... the header
... the payload
... the trailer
suggestedAnswer: Data split into packets routed independently.

question: Data is broken down into smaller units to be transmitted from one device to another.\nGive the name of the unit that data is broken down into.
oldAnswer: Packet
suggestedAnswer: Data split into packets routed independently.

question: Describe how an Automatic Repeat Request (ARQ) system is used to check for errors.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The sender transmits a data packet
... and waits for an acknowledgement (ACK)
If no ACK is received within a timeout period
... or if a negative acknowledgement (NACK) is received
The sender retransmits the packet
This process repeats until an ACK is received or a limit is reached
suggestedAnswer: Data split into packets routed independently.

question: Explain what a checksum is and how it is used.
oldAnswer:
A checksum is a value computed from the data
The sender transmits it with the packet
The receiver recomputes the checksum
... and compares it to the received checksum to detect errors
suggestedAnswer: Data split into packets routed independently.

question: Name the three buses in Von Neumann architecture and state their roles.
oldAnswer: Data bus carries data; Address bus carries memory addresses; Control bus carries control signals.
suggestedAnswer: Directs operations of the processor.

question: Describe the stored program concept.
oldAnswer: Instructions and data are stored in the same memory unit\n... and are accessed via the same buses.
suggestedAnswer: Directs operations of the processor.

question: Name the three buses in Von Neumann architecture and state their roles.
oldAnswer: Data bus carries data; Address bus carries memory addresses; Control bus carries control signals.
suggestedAnswer: Fast memory storing frequently accessed data.

question: Describe the stored program concept.
oldAnswer: Instructions and data are stored in the same memory unit\n... and are accessed via the same buses.
suggestedAnswer: Fast memory storing frequently accessed data.

question: Describe the steps of the Fetch-Execute cycle.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The PC holds the address of the next instruction
The address is copied to the MAR
The address is sent along the address bus
The instruction is fetched from that address in memory
... and transferred to the MDR
The instruction is sent to the CIR
The PC is incremented
The instruction is decoded and executed
suggestedAnswer: Fast memory storing frequently accessed data.

question: Explain how clock speed and cache size affect CPU performance.
oldAnswer: Clock speed: Higher speed means more cycles per second, so more instructions can be processed.\nCache size: Larger cache stores more frequently used instructions/data closer to the CPU, reducing access time compared to RAM.
suggestedAnswer: Fast memory storing frequently accessed data.

question: Compare RAM and ROM with one use case for each.
oldAnswer: RAM is volatile working memory used during program execution. ROM is non-volatile and stores firmware that runs at start-up.
suggestedAnswer: Fast memory storing frequently accessed data.

question: Explain the purpose of Virtual Memory.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
It is used when RAM is full
Data not currently in use is moved from RAM to secondary storage (HDD/SSD)
... creating 'pages'
It extends the available memory for running programs
Data is swapped back to RAM when needed
suggestedAnswer: Fast memory storing frequently accessed data.

question: Describe the stored program concept.
oldAnswer: Instructions and data are stored in the same memory unit\n... and are accessed via the same buses.
suggestedAnswer: Transfers actual data between components.

question: Describe the steps of the Fetch-Execute cycle.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The PC holds the address of the next instruction
The address is copied to the MAR
The address is sent along the address bus
The instruction is fetched from that address in memory
... and transferred to the MDR
The instruction is sent to the CIR
The PC is incremented
The instruction is decoded and executed
suggestedAnswer: Transfers actual data between components.

question: Explain how clock speed and cache size affect CPU performance.
oldAnswer: Clock speed: Higher speed means more cycles per second, so more instructions can be processed.\nCache size: Larger cache stores more frequently used instructions/data closer to the CPU, reducing access time compared to RAM.
suggestedAnswer: Transfers actual data between components.

question: Describe how data is written to and read from optical storage.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
A laser beam is used to read/write data
Data is stored as pits and lands
... on a spiral track
When reading, the laser is reflected differently by pits and lands
... which is interpreted as binary 1s and 0s
suggestedAnswer: Transfers actual data between components.

question: A greenhouse system controls temperature automatically. Describe how the system uses sensors and actuators to maintain temperature.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The temperature sensor constantly measures the temperature
It sends analogue data to the ADC
... which converts it to digital data for the microprocessor
The microprocessor compares the reading to a pre-set value
If temperature < pre-set value, it signals the actuator
... to turn on the heater
If temperature > pre-set value, it signals the actuator to turn off the heater/open windows
suggestedAnswer: Transfers actual data between components.

question: Explain the function of the ALU and Control Unit in a CPU.
oldAnswer: The ALU performs arithmetic and logic operations; the Control Unit fetches, decodes and coordinates execution of instructions.
suggestedAnswer: Carries control signals coordinating operations.

question: Describe the steps of the Fetch-Execute cycle.

The PC holds the address of the next instruction
The address is copied to the MAR
The address is sent along the address bus
The instruction is fetched from that address in memory
... and transferred to the MDR
The instruction is sent to the CIR
The PC is incremented
The instruction is decoded and executed
suggestedAnswer: Carries control signals coordinating operations.

question: Explain why a programmer might choose to write code in Assembly Language.
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
To have direct control over the hardware
To write code that occupies less memory
To write code that executes faster/more efficiently
No need for a compiler/interpreter (only assembler needed)
Specific hardware drivers often require low-level access
suggestedAnswer: Allocation and control of primary memory.

question: State two functions of an operating system.
oldAnswer: Examples: memory management, file management, process scheduling, device control, security.
suggestedAnswer: Scheduling and control of running tasks.

question: Describe how an interrupt is handled by the CPU.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The CPU completes the current fetch-execute cycle
The contents of the registers (PC/ACC) are saved
... to the stack
The source of the interrupt is identified
The appropriate Interrupt Service Routine (ISR) is called/executed
Once the ISR is complete, the saved register values are restored
... from the stack
The CPU continues with the next instruction of the original program
suggestedAnswer: Human-readable program text.

question: Compare compiler and interpreter.
oldAnswer: A compiler translates the whole program into object code before execution; an interpreter translates and executes line by line at runtime.
suggestedAnswer: Human-readable program text.

question: State two advantages of using a High-Level Language (HLL) compared to a Low-Level Language (LLL).
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
Easier to understand/read/write (for humans)
... as it uses English-like statements
Easier to debug/find errors
Portable/machine independent
... code can run on different hardware without rewrite
suggestedAnswer: Human-readable program text.

To write code that executes faster/more efficiently
No need for a compiler/interpreter (only assembler needed)
Specific hardware drivers often require low-level access
suggestedAnswer: Language close to machine operations and hardware.

question: Describe how an interrupt is handled by the CPU.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The CPU completes the current fetch-execute cycle
The contents of the registers (PC/ACC) are saved
... to the stack
The source of the interrupt is identified
The appropriate Interrupt Service Routine (ISR) is called/executed
Once the ISR is complete, the saved register values are restored
... from the stack
The CPU continues with the next instruction of the original program
suggestedAnswer: Software released with source code and permissive license.

question: State one advantage of open-source software and one advantage of proprietary software.
oldAnswer: Open-source: free to use/modify; community support; transparency.\nProprietary: dedicated vendor support; regular updates; polished features.
suggestedAnswer: Software released with source code and permissive license.

question: Explain the difference between system software and application software.
oldAnswer: System software manages and supports computer operations; application software performs user-facing tasks.
suggestedAnswer: Software licensed with restricted use and access.

question: Describe the role of DNS in accessing websites.
oldAnswer:
Any two from:
A user enters a URL/domain name in the browser
The DNS system is queried to resolve the name
DNS servers maintain a distributed database of domain names and IP addresses
If the local DNS does not have the record, it queries other DNS servers
The DNS returns the corresponding IP address to the client
The browser uses the IP address to connect to the web server
DNS may cache results to speed up future lookups
suggestedAnswer: Interlinked documents and resources accessed via browsers.

question: Explain the difference between HTTP and HTTPS.
oldAnswer:
HTTP:
Data is sent in plain text
... so it can be intercepted/read by a third party
Does not provide authentication of the server

HTTPS:
Uses TLS/SSL to encrypt communication
... so intercepted data cannot be understood
Verifies the identity of the web server (via digital certificates)
suggestedAnswer: Interlinked documents and resources accessed via browsers.

question: State two advantages of using HTTPS when shopping online.
oldAnswer: Encrypts data to prevent interception/read by third parties\nAuthenticates the web server via digital certificates
suggestedAnswer: Interlinked documents and resources accessed via browsers.

question: Explain the difference between phishing and pharming.
oldAnswer:
Phishing:
Involves sending fraudulent emails/messages
... to trick users into revealing personal data (by clicking links)

Pharming:
Involves malicious code installed on a user's hard drive or web server
... which redirects the user to a fake website (even if correct URL is typed)
... without the user's knowledge
suggestedAnswer: Interlinked documents and resources accessed via browsers.

question: Explain how a digital signature is used to verify the authenticity of a document.
oldAnswer:
Any three from:
A hash/digest of the document is created
... using a hashing algorithm
The hash is encrypted using the sender's private key
... to create the digital signature
The receiver decrypts the signature using the sender's public key
... to get the original hash
The receiver recalculates the hash of the received document
If the two hashes match, the document is authentic and unaltered
suggestedAnswer: Electronic document verifying identity and public key.

question: Explain the difference between HTTP and HTTPS.
oldAnswer:
HTTP:
Data is sent in plain text
... so it can be intercepted/read by a third party
Does not provide authentication of the server

HTTPS:
Uses TLS/SSL to encrypt communication
... so intercepted data cannot be understood
Verifies the identity of the web server (via digital certificates)
suggestedAnswer: Cryptographic proof of content integrity and origin.

question: State two advantages of using HTTPS when shopping online.
oldAnswer: Encrypts data to prevent interception/read by third parties\nAuthenticates the web server via digital certificates
suggestedAnswer: Cryptographic proof of content integrity and origin.

question: Describe the process of SSL/TLS handshaking.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The client sends a request to the server to establish a secure connection
The server sends its digital certificate to the client
... which includes the server's public key
The client verifies the digital certificate (authenticity and date)
The client generates a session key
... encrypts it with the server's public key
... and sends it to the server
The server decrypts the session key with its private key
Both parties now use the session key for encrypted communication
suggestedAnswer: Cryptographic proof of content integrity and origin.

question: Trace this pseudocode and state the final value of total given input n=5.
oldAnswer: For i from 1 to 5, total accumulates 15. Final value: 15.
suggestedAnswer: Table tracking variable values step by step.

question: Explain the difference between a WHILE loop and a REPEAT...UNTIL loop.
oldAnswer: WHILE loop checks the condition at the start (pre-condition) and may not run at all. REPEAT...UNTIL checks the condition at the end (post-condition) and always runs at least once.
suggestedAnswer: Manual simulation of code to check logic.

question: Identify three types of test data used to test a system.
oldAnswer: Normal data (valid/typical), Boundary data (extreme ends of valid range), Erroneous/Abnormal data (invalid).
suggestedAnswer: Structured approach outlining tests to validate software.

question: Identify three types of test data used to test a system.
oldAnswer: Normal data (valid/typical), Boundary data (extreme ends of valid range), Erroneous/Abnormal data (invalid).
suggestedAnswer: Inputs with incorrect types or invalid values.

question: Describe how a Bubble Sort algorithm sorts a list of numbers into ascending order.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The algorithm loops through the list
It compares each pair of adjacent elements
If they are in the wrong order, it swaps them
It records that a swap has occurred
It repeats the loop until a pass is made with no swaps
suggestedAnswer: Building sorted list by inserting elements into position.

question: Describe how a Bubble Sort algorithm sorts a list of numbers into ascending order.
oldAnswer:
Any four from:
The algorithm loops through the list
It compares each pair of adjacent elements
If they are in the wrong order, it swaps them
It records that a swap has occurred
It repeats the loop until a pass is made with no swaps
suggestedAnswer: Divide and conquer sorting by merging sorted sublists.
